data.title: Are college basketball jobs more stable than college football?
data.meta_description: Bo Ryan announced the other day that he was stepping down as the Wisconsin basketball coach after next season. Syracuse’s Jim Boeheim has also given his target date (2018). It got me to thinking. \n I…
data.text:
Bo Ryan announced the other day that he was stepping down as the Wisconsin basketball coach after next season. Syracuse’s Jim Boeheim has also given his target date (2018). It got me to thinking.

It seems like basketball coaching jobs are a lot more stable than football. But is it true?

No football coach can match the longevity of Boeheim (hired in 1976) or Mike Krzyzewski (1980) at Duke. But after those two, football coaches match basketball coaches.

Football has Frank Beamer, hired at Virginia Tech in 1987; Bob Stoops, Oklahoma 1999; Kirk Ferentz, Iowa 1999; Gary Patterson, TCU 2000; Mark Richt, Georgia 2001; and Gary Pinkel, Missouri 2001.

Basketball counters with Tom Izzo, Michigan State 1995; Kevin Stallings, Vanderbilt 1999; Mike Brey, Notre Dame 2000; Ryan, Wisconsin 2001; and Rick Pitino, Louisville 2001.

So of the 13 longest-standing coaches in Power-5 conferences, both football and basketball, hoops has only a 7-6 advantage.

Now, after that, basketball shows a little more stability. No current football coach was hired in 2002, 2003 or 2004. Nine basketball coaches still on the job were hired during those years.

Mike Gundy, hired at OSU in 2005, is the No. 7 active football coach among the 65 major schools. He’s tied with Utah’s Kyle Whittingham, South Carolina’s Steve Spurrier and LSU’s Les Miles, who departure from OSU is what opened the job for Gundy.

But that 2002-04 window is the only major discrepancy.

Fourteen football coaches hired from 2005-09 remain on the job; only 11 basketball coaches hired those five years remain on the job.

And everything evens out in the last five years.

So what does this tell us? Well, I’d say it’s easier to be a decades-long coach in basketball than in football. Three hoops coaches have been on the job at least 20 years; two of those are approaching 40 years. Only Beamer has busted the 20 mark in football.

The pressure to win is the only compelling reason for the differences. In fact, basketball coaches have more opportunity to move, because there are a variety of hoops jobs outside the Power-5 leagues that are prestigious. The Big East schools, Memphis, Cincinnati, that crowd. Not near that many in football.

Yet basketball jobs are a little more stable. I think we know why. Conference realignment taught us that basketball is not quite as important. A coach like Andy Kennedy, on the job since 2006, can last a long time at Ole Miss without big-time results. The Mississippi football coach is not given that luxury. Travis Ford’s failure to get over the hump in basketball is accepted by Stillwater brass, because it would cost too much to make a change. OSU would not hesitate to eat the contract if it was football.

And some of the basketball jobs at non-football power schools are incredibly stable. Jay Wright’s been at Villanova since 2001, John Thompson’s been at Georgetown since 2004, Mick Cronin’s been at Cincinnati since 2006 and Fran Dunphy’s been at Temple since 2006.

All in all, though, I was surprised at how well football coaches have fared in this chart. I would have thought basketball would dominate. Except for the Boeheim/Coach K and the 2002-04 window, there is no discernible difference.
